title: 109_s1519
content: The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005, also known as the Small Business Act, is amended to include a new section 37 regarding agency restructuring or termination of facility use. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 is amended to include definitions for terms like agency, qualifying termination or restructuring, restructuring, small governmental jurisdiction, and State. The act also outlines that a qualifying termination or restructuring involves a net loss of at least 1,000 jobs in any State. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires agencies and other entities to conduct a detailed economic analysis on the impact of proposed terminations or restructurings on small businesses and small governmental jurisdictions before finalizing any recommendations. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates a thorough economic analysis of the effects of proposed terminations or restructurings on small businesses and small governmental jurisdictions. This analysis includes identifying affected small businesses and jurisdictions, efforts to minimize adverse impacts, and exploring alternative solutions to reduce overall impact. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires a cost-benefit analysis of the economic impact on small businesses and governmental jurisdictions for proposed terminations or restructurings exceeding $100,000,000 in any State. This analysis must be conducted in accordance with Office of Management and Budget Circular A-4 principles. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates a cost-benefit analysis for proposed terminations or restructurings exceeding $100,000,000. The analysis must evaluate costs and benefits to small businesses and governmental jurisdictions, provide alternatives, and ensure transparency in the process. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires agencies to ensure transparency in cost-benefit analysis by incorporating an executive summary, detailing assumptions and discount rates, referencing data sources, and providing appendices. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates agencies to publish draft and final economic analyses on their websites and in the Federal Register, with a period for public comment. Additionally, agencies must include documentation of models used and results of sensitivity and uncertainty analyses. After publishing the final economic analysis, an agency must submit it to the Comptroller General of the United States for review within 90 days. If the analysis is deemed insufficient, the agency must redo the procedures. Final action on a termination or restructuring cannot be taken until a satisfactory review is received from the Comptroller General. Judicial review of qualifying termination or restructuring can be sought by small businesses or governmental jurisdictions within 90 days of final economic analysis publication. The review is limited to determining if the action is arbitrary, capricious, or not in accordance with the law. The Small Business Act requires an economic analysis for qualifying termination or restructuring actions. Judicial review can be sought within 90 days to ensure compliance with the law.
